author: abock
body:
PowerShell does not parse comment based help for a script unless the help comment starts on the first line of the script. This prevents scripts employing a [shebang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shebang_(Unix)) from being helpful via `Get-Help`.

PowerShell should skip the first line of a script file if it starts with `#!`.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

Create a new script called `thing.ps1` with a shebang:

```powershell
#!/usr/bin/env pwsh
<#
.SYNOPSIS
This does a thing
#>
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```powershell
PS> Get-Help thing.ps1

NAME
    /Users/aaron/src/thing.ps1

SYNOPSIS
    This does a thing

…
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```powershell
PS> Get-Help thing.ps1
thing.ps1
…
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
PS> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.0-beta.9
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-beta.9
OS                             Darwin 16.7.0 Darwin Kernel Version 16.7.0: Thu Jun 15 17:36:27 PDT 2017; root:xnu...
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: abock
comments.body:
Note, this is an issue with both syntaxes:

```powershell
#!/usr/bin/env pwsh
# .SYNOPSIS
# This does a thing
```

comments.author: Jaykul
comments.body:
This is *definitely* a bug. However ... 

You just need a blank line between the shebang and the help to work around it.

comments.author: cspotcode
comments.body: Is this because contiguous spans of comments are all grouped together, so the help system considers the shebang and the synopsis to be the same comment?

title: Comment based help does not work for scripts that start with a shebang
